DOCNAME: CASE OF MILD AND VIRTANEN v. FINLAND
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-1+6-3-d;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants were born in DATE and DATE respectively and live in PERSON .

CARDINAL . A shop selling fur coats in PERSON was burgled on DATE . CARDINAL men , PERSON and NORP , were charged with aggravated theft before ORG of PERSON ( käräjäoikeus , tingsrätten ) . On DATE ORG convicted them both as charged . The convictions were based on their acknowledgement of the charges .

CARDINAL . The police investigation concerning the applicants as suspects in the above - mentioned offence began on CARDINAL DATE , when they were taken into police custody . The first applicant was arrested on CARDINAL DATE by a decision of ORG . The second applicant was arrested on DATE , but released in TIME .

CARDINAL . The criminal proceedings against the applicants were instituted before the above ORG on DATE . They were charged with aggravated theft . They were suspected of having stolen fur coats worth MONEY ( ORG ; MONEY ( ORG ) ) as accomplices with PERSON and NORP , who had already been convicted of the same offence . The applicants denied the charges .

CARDINAL . According to the indictment , the applicants visited the fur shop in DATE and made themselves familiar with the shop and its merchandise . The second applicant tried on headgear and promised to collect it DATE after it had been altered to fit her . The applicants did not , however , return to the shop at the agreed time , or later . During their visit to the shop , the first applicant requested to see the most expensive fur coat and the salesman showed him a rack with the most expensive furs . Later on , the first applicant proposed to PERSON to steal fur coats from the shop . At the end of February M. and the applicants contacted NORP , who lived in the GPE area , and apparently PERSON asked NORP to take part in the burglary . Having rented or borrowed a ORG Chevy van from NORP on DATE , NORP and PERSON drove to PERSON , the applicants driving ahead of them in their light coloured PERSON . PERSON and NORP spent TIME in the applicants’ home in PERSON . The following day , i.e. on DATE , the first applicant showed PERSON and NORP the fur shop by driving past it a couple of times in the above - mentioned Opel . Then all CARDINAL of them returned to the apartment . The applicants stayed at home while PERSON and NORP returned to the shop in the van , broke into the shop and stole the fur coats . Immediately after the burglary PERSON and NORP left for PERSON , a town in the GPE area . The applicants followed PERSON and NORP to PERSON in their own car . Together they hid the fur coats in a garage rented by the first applicant . Later on , the first applicant , PERSON and NORP began to market the fur coats .

CARDINAL . M. and NORP were not present as the summons to appear before the court had not been served upon them . The public prosecutor referred in evidence to the statements given by them during their own police investigation . According to PERSON ’s statement , the first applicant had told him that the applicants had visited the shop in order to buy headgear and while there , he had got the idea of stealing the furs . The first applicant had proposed that PERSON break into the shop . PERSON had considered the proposal and eventually , DATE , accepted it as he was in need of money . According to PERSON , the applicants did not take part in the burglary . In the beginning , the first applicant had said that the money would be divided into CARDINAL parts , i.e. the second applicant would also have got her share . In NORP ’s statement to the police he said that the first applicant had told him about his plans of breaking into a fur shop , which the applicants had visited in order to buy something for the second applicant . NORP could not , however , remember whether it was PERSON or the first applicant who had asked him to join them . NORP told the police that he and PERSON had driven to PERSON in the van , following the applicants . They had spent TIME at the applicants’ apartment . DATE , the first applicant , PERSON and NORP went to have a look at the shop in the first applicant ’s car . In TIME PERSON and NORP returned to the shop , while the applicants stayed at the apartment . After the burglary they all left for GPE , but in CARDINAL separate cars . They all met twice for coffee during the journey . Having reached GPE , they went to a garage to which the first applicant had the keys . Later on PERSON and the first applicant began to market the furs . According to NORP , the burglary was the first applicant ’s idea . PERSON and NORP had not even visited PERSON before the burglary .

CARDINAL . At this point the applicants’ counsel noted that if the applicants were to be convicted on the basis of the statements given by PERSON and NORP , they should be heard in person before the court .

CARDINAL . The fur shop ’s salesman PERSON gave testimony before ORG . He identified the applicants as the couple who had visited his shop in DATE . DATE of the burglary he had noticed a white car driving by with CARDINAL men in it . All CARDINAL had turned their heads looking at the shop , but they had been too far away to recognize .

CARDINAL . The lender of the van , NORP , was heard as a witness before the court . He repeated his statement given during the police investigation , inter alia , that having been questioned by the police [ on CARDINAL DATE ] he was contacted by the first applicant , who wanted to know what NORP had told the police , but before ORG D. was no longer certain as to whether it was the first applicant or NORP who had queried what he had told the police . NORP was also uncertain as to whether he had seen the applicants in NORP ’s company before lending his van or after it had been returned to him . Furthermore , NORP said that at the relevant time he was selling and buying cars and that he had discussed a car deal with the first applicant when they met . NORP also said that his van did not carry any stickers or the like .

CARDINAL . Police officer Y. was also heard as a witness before ORG . He told the court that he had in general kept an eye on the first applicant as he was aware of his past . DATE of the burglary he had seen a van parked in the parking lot outside the applicants’ apartment . He was not certain as to whether it was the same van as the one used by PERSON and NORP in the burglary . Y. had noticed that the van carried a yellow sticker from which he had concluded that the car originated from the GPE area .

CARDINAL . At this point the public prosecutor referred to the first applicant ’s statement during the police investigation according to which he did not remember ever visiting the fur shop , but that he might have gone there while DATE shopping . Moreover , the first applicant had told the police that he had discussed a car deal with NORP , but he had concealed the fact that he had been present when the van was returned .

CARDINAL . NORP The public prosecutor referred to the second applicant ’s statement during the police investigation , according to which she denied having ever visited the fur shop or that PERSON and NORP had spent TIME at the applicants’ apartment in GPE . Furthermore , she told the police that she had visited a friend , PERSON , in GPE , on DATE of the burglary .

CARDINAL . NORP The public prosecutor pointed out that I. when questioned as a witness by the police [ on DATE ] did not confirm the second applicant ’s story . According to ORG , the second applicant had rung her DATE and asked her to give her an alibi . I. was not heard before ORG during this session .
CARDINAL . ORG adjourned the case until DATE , ordering the public prosecutor to call PERSON and NORP , who were in liberty , to be heard before the court .
CARDINAL . On DATE , the public prosecutor requested that the case be adjourned as PERSON and NORP had not been summoned yet . ORG adjourned the case until DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the case was heard before the court again . PERSON and NORP were absent even though they had been summoned . The public prosecutor noted that according to LAW ) of ORG , the applicants had a right to examine or have examined the witnesses against them , but that right was not unconditional . He referred to CARDINAL judgments of this Court ( PERSON v. GPE , judgment of DATE , Series A no . CARDINAL and PERSON v. GPE , judgment of CARDINAL DATE , Series A no . CARDINALA ) . In particular , the public prosecutor referred to the principle according to which there was no violation of LAW ) , if the conviction was primarily based on other evidence submitted during the trial . In this respect , he referred to the evidence given by the witnesses and argued that the applicants could be convicted even though they had not been able to examine PERSON and NORP as witnesses during these proceedings . ORG again adjourned the case until DATE , ordering the public prosecutor to summon PERSON and NORP to be heard before the court .

CARDINAL . On DATE M. sent a facsimile to ORG , withdrawing all his statements during the police investigation concerning the applicants as they were false . He alleged that he had personal reasons to make erroneous statements and , while in detention , had been given to understand that such statements could contribute to his release . Moreover , he informed the court that he was aware of the fact that he could not be forced to appear before ORG . PERSON ’s facsimile was communicated to the applicants and to the public prosecutor at the hearing of CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE , ORG rejected the charges against the applicants as it found that the mere fact that PERSON had given evidence that the applicants had visited his shop as customers in DATE and that the van used in the burglary had been seen parked in the parking lot close to the applicants’ apartment did not show that the applicants had committed the offence with which they were charged .

CARDINAL . NORP The public prosecutor appealed to ORG ( hovioikeus , hovrätten ) , requesting that the applicants be convicted as charged . According to him , the evidence presented before ORG , taking into account also the statements of PERSON and NORP , was strong enough to justify a conviction .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG held an oral hearing , in which the applicants , PERSON , NORP and NORP were reheard . NORP clarified that the applicants had been in PERSON ’s and NORP ’s company when the van was returned to him and that it was the first applicant who had queried what NORP had told the police when he was questioned .

CARDINAL . In addition NORP was heard as a witness before ORG . She testified that the second applicant had visited her in PERSON in TIME DATE . I. was certain that the first applicant had dropped the second applicant off at the apartment and then picked her up TIME . According to ORG , the version given to ORG was the truth . When questioned by the police , she had not been able to tell the truth due to the police officer ’s unpleasant attitude towards her . At that time , she did not want to get involved in the case .
CARDINAL . M. and NORP were not summoned and they were not heard before ORG . Nor did the applicants request that PERSON and NORP be heard .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG convicted the first applicant of aggravated theft and sentenced him to DATE and CARDINAL months’ imprisonment . The second applicant was convicted of aiding and abetting the above - mentioned offence by visiting the fur shop together with the first applicant . She was sentenced to a suspended term of CARDINAL months’ imprisonment . ORG , having first referred to the ORG ’s judgments PERSON v. GPE and PERSON v. GPE , cited above , found that :

“ PERSON ’s and NORP ’s statements concerning the events given during their police investigation and repeated before ORG [ in their own case ] are supported by other evidence presented in the present case . PERSON observed the applicants visit the fur shop and NORP noted the presence of the applicants when the borrowed van was returned to him . Moreover , the first applicant showed an interest in what NORP had told the police . Furthermore , the statements of PERSON and NORP are supported by Y. ’s observation of NORP ’s van in PERSON close to the applicants’ apartment .

Even though the applicants did not have an opportunity to put questions to PERSON and NORP , they had an opportunity to submit arguments against their statements , both during the police investigation and also before ORG as well as ORG . The applicants have , nevertheless , denied having ever visited the fur shop , which , taking into account the certainty of PERSON as to the applicants’ identity , tends to diminish the credibility of the applicants’ statements .

ORG does not find that the changing of ORG statement - or the reasons given for the change - are credible . ORG finds it irrelevant that PERSON has , in a facsimile submitted to ORG , retracted his earlier statement . ”

CARDINAL . The applicants requested leave to appeal from ORG ( korkein oikeus , högsta domstolen ) , arguing that they should have had a right to examine PERSON and NORP before the courts , as the other evidence was not strong enough to support their convictions . The alleged fact that they had visited a shop or passed by it did not prove that they had committed the serious offences they were convicted of . Furthermore , on DATE of their alleged visit to the fur shop they had both been at an oral hearing before ORG of Espoo , which is situated QUANTITY from PERSON , and could not even in theory have been at the shop at the time mentioned in the judgment . The applicants later submitted to ORG a copy of ORG DATE in support of their argument .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG refused the applicants leave to appeal .

CARDINAL . LAW , section CARDINAL of the Judicial Procedure Code provides that a person who has earlier been convicted of an offence which is the subject of pending court proceedings may be heard in the case , but not in the capacity of a witness or party to the proceedings .
CARDINAL . At the time of the proceedings there were , however , no provisions of law under which such a person could have been forced to appear before a court .
